subject: RE: [junit] test method with arguments?
msgSnippet: Hi JB, I ve done a google for Parameterized Test Case pattern , but failed to find anything concrete about it. Could briefly explain it (written or code)- I m
messageBody:
Hi JB,

I've done a google for "Parameterized Test Case pattern", but failed to find
anything concrete about it.

Could briefly explain it (written or code)- I'm always looking for ways to
improve how my team develop tests and I'm sure the rest of this list would
find it useful.

Regards

Andrew

> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
> Sent: 29 March 2004 17:27
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] test method with arguments?
>
>
> Andrew McDonagh wrote:
> >
> > I use the following pattern...
> >
> >
> > public void testVariousParams() {
> > paramTest("a param";
> > paramTest("second test param");
> > ....
> > }
> >
> > private void paramTest(String expectedValue) {
> > Something something = new Something();
> > assertEquals("didn't work", expectedvalue, something.getValue());
> > }
> >
> >
> > The only issue is that the private test case methods cannot be named
> > test**** as the JUnit framework moans about them being private or having
> > params.
>
> Extract testVariousParams() into the suite() method and you have the
> beginnings of the Parameterized Test Case pattern. The above is exactly
> how I used to do it.
> --
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> Let's write software that people understand
